channel.title: Andrea's TiddlyWiki
channel.description: a reusable non-linear personal web notebook

item.title: Kangoh Lee
item.description:
! The paper
The paper presented today is a metaphor for some important human capital questions: when is the right time to switch from general to specific human capital? How should institutions be designed so that people make the efficient investment choices? etc... I think these are great questions, some of which I have been playing with myself.

The presenter has chosen to use they olympics as a metaphor for the labor market. From a theoretical perspective, this is questionable, because when you have a choice you should always choose the application that gives you the greater payoff. From the point of view of the presentation, it made the audience's life difficult: I struggled continuously to make a connection between the application and the labor market: is training for the olympics equivalent to acquiring specific human capital? Is the choosing the outside option equivalent to stop training? The best parallel that I could make is that selection for the olympics is like forcing people to acquire specific human capital (say, vocational education). But that is not quire right, because even when one is selected, there is still the choice not to train.

Anyhow, let's stick to the application that was the matter of study. Ultimately, under the assumptions, delayed selection is always good. Hence early selection is optimal only if the cost of training is relatively high compared to the benefits from the medals. This is fine, however we don't need a model with uncertainty to get this. The model is missing entirely other dimensions that are relevant, some of which have been raised already: superstars might make early selection more efficient, reducing team selection uncertainty for the good guys, etc...

Personally, when I read a theoretical paper I need to be instructed about tradeoffs that are not that obvious; even if the results depend on parameter values, I would like to know how the characterization of which parameter affect the outcome might inform me about the real world. I think this paper falls short of that goal by a great deal. The main problem is that the puzzle here is mostly empirical, and the answer depends on various aspects of the job (in this case, sport), of the nature of uncertainty, etc... which are either ignored ore are not relevant in the model, therefore I don't really gain any theoretical insights.

What is the right stopping rule for human capital investment, when should we switch from general education to professional education? There is enough institutional variation across countries that grants a deeper understanding of what the tradeoffs at play are. We do need models that address and explain these tradeoffs, that tell us why countries make different choices. I think this paper does not address these issues in a satisfactory way. Moreover, I beliefve that these questions are mostly empirical, and a better attention to the data could inform a better way to write such models. But the candidate seems to pay only lip service to the idea that he should get his hands dirty with the data.

! The presentation
I second Erica's #2. I found that a bit annoying

! The candidate
The fact that he gets so much published is indeed impressive and does deserve our consideration. I believe that on the basis of the job talk alone the candidate is below the bar. The cv however puts him above. And for a senior candidate we should place a greater weight on the cv. I checked one tax evasion paper in JPubE: that was another paper where the distance between assumptions and conclusion was dangerously small. The candidate was certainly lucky in that occasion. If we want to hire this guy, we need to check the other papers.

item.title: ListReversePlugin
item.description:
/***
|''Name:''|ListReversePlugin |
|''Version:''|0.9.0 |
|''Source:''|http://www.legolas.org/gmwiki/dev/gmwikidev.html#ListReversePlugin |
|''Author:''|[[DevonJones]] |
|''Type:''|List Macro Extension |
|''License:''|BSD |
|''Requires:''|TiddlyWiki 1.2.32 or higher (tested only on 1.2.36, but should work on 1.2.32)|
!Description
Extends the TiddlyWiki ''list'' macro by adding the capability to reverse the order of any other list macro.

!Syntax
* {{{<>}}}
* {{{<>}}}

!Sample Output
''Example:'' lists all orphan tiddlers in reverse.
{{{<>}}}
<>

!Known issues

!Notes
* Is known to work with my CslPlugin and Paul Petterson's ListWithTagsPlugin

!Revision history
v0.9.0 October 19th 2005 - initial release

!Code
***/
//{{{

config.macros.list.reverse = {}

config.macros.list.reverse.handler = function(params) {
var list = config.macros["list"];
params.shift();
var type = params[0] ? params[0] : "all";
results = list[type].handler(params);
results = results.sort( function(a,b) {
if(a["title"] != null) {
return ( a["title"] < b["title"] ) - (a["title"] > b["title"] )
}
else {
return (a < b) - (a > b);
}
});
return results;
}

//}}}

item.title: StyleSheetColors
item.description:
/***
!Colors Used
*@@background-color:#8cf; <> Background blue@@
*@@bgcolor(#18f): #18f - Top blue@@
*@@bgcolor(#04b): #04b - Mid blue@@
*@@bgcolor(#014):color(#fff): #014 - Bottom blue@@
*@@bgcolor(#ffc): #ffc - Bright yellow@@
*@@bgcolor(#fe8): #fe8 - Highlight yellow@@
*@@bgcolor(#db4): #db4 - Background yellow@@
*@@bgcolor(#841): #841 - Border yellow@@
*@@bgcolor(#703):color(#fff): #703 - Title red@@
*@@bgcolor(#866): #866 - Subtitle grey@@
!Generic Rules /%==============================================%/
***/
/*{{{*/
body {
background: [[ColorMainBackground]];
color: [[ColorMainColor]];
}

a{
color: [[ColorThree]];
}

a:hover{
background: [[ColorThree]];
color: [[ColorMainBackground]];
}

a img{
border: 0;
}

h1,h2,h3,h4,h5 {
color: [[ColorNine]];
background: [[ColorOne]];
}

.button {
color: [[ColorFour]];
border: 1px solid [[ColorMainBackground]];
}

.button:hover {
color: [[ColorFour]];
background: [[ColorSix]];
border: 1px solid [[ColorSeven]];
}

.button:active {
color: [[ColorMainBackground]];
background: [[ColorSeven]];
border: 1px solid [[ColorEight]];
}

/*}}}*/
/***
!Header /%==================================================%/
***/
/*{{{*/
.header {
background: [[ColorThree]];
}

.headerShadow {
color: [[ColorMainColor]];
}

.headerShadow a {
font-weight: normal;
color: [[ColorMainColor]];
}

.headerForeground {
color: [[ColorMainBackground]];
}

.headerForeground a {
font-weight: normal;
color: [[ColorOne]];
}

/*}}}*/
/***
!General tabs /%=================================================%/
***/
/*{{{*/

.tabSelected{
color: [[ColorFour]];
background: #eee;
border-left: 1px solid #ccc;
border-top: 1px solid #ccc;
border-right: 1px solid #ccc;
}

.tabUnselected {
color: [[ColorMainBackground]];
background: #999;
}

.tabContents {
color: [[ColorFour]];
background: #eee;
border: 1px solid #ccc;
}

.tabContents .button {
border: 0;}

/*}}}*/
/***
!Sidebar options /%=================================================%/
~TiddlyLinks and buttons are treated identically in the sidebar and slider panel
***/
/*{{{*/
#sidebar {
}

#sidebarOptions input {
border: 1px solid [[ColorThree]];
}

#sidebarOptions .sliderPanel {
background: [[ColorOne]];
}

#sidebarOptions .sliderPanel a {
border: none;
color: [[ColorThree]];
}

#sidebarOptions .sliderPanel a:hover {
color: [[ColorMainBackground]];
background: [[ColorThree]];
}

#sidebarOptions .sliderPanel a:active {
color: [[ColorThree]];
background: [[ColorMainBackground]];
}
/*}}}*/
/***
!Message Area /%=================================================%/
***/
/*{{{*/
#messageArea {
border: 1px solid [[ColorEight]];
background: [[ColorSeven]];
color: [[ColorFour]];
}

#messageArea .button {
padding: 0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.2em;
color: [[ColorFour]];
background: [[ColorMainBackground]];
}

/*}}}*/
/***
!Popup /%=================================================%/
***/
/*{{{*/
.popup {
background: [[ColorTwo]];
border: 1px solid [[ColorThree]];
}

.popup hr {
color: [[ColorFour]];
background: [[ColorFour]];
border-bottom: 1px;
}

.popup li.disabled {
color: [[ColorThree]];
}

.popup li a, .popup li a:visited {
color: #eee;
border: none;
}

.popup li a:hover {
background: [[ColorFour]];
color: [[ColorMainBackground]];
border: none;
}
/*}}}*/
/***
!Tiddler Display /%=================================================%/
***/
/*{{{*/
.tiddler .defaultCommand {
font-weight: bold;
}

.shadow .title {
color: [[ColorTen]];
}

.title {
color: [[ColorNine]];
}

.subtitle {
color: [[ColorTen]];
}

.toolbar {
color: [[ColorThree]];
}

.tagging, .tagged {
border: 1px solid #eee;
background-color: #eee;
}

.selected .tagging, .selected .tagged {
background-color: #ddd;
border: 1px solid #bbb;
}

.tagging .listTitle, .tagged .listTitle {
color: [[ColorFour]];
}

.tagging .button, .tagged .button {
border: none;
}

.footer {
color: #ddd;
}

.selected .footer {
color: #888;
}

.sparkline {
background: [[ColorOne]];
border: 0;
}

.sparktick {
background: [[ColorFour]];
}

.errorButton {
color: #ff0;
background: #f00;
}

.cascade {
background: #eef;
color: #aac;
border: 1px solid #aac;
}

.imageLink, #displayArea .imageLink {
background: transparent;
}

/*}}}*/
/***
''The viewer is where the tiddler content is displayed'' /%------------------------------------------------%/
***/
/*{{{*/

.viewer .listTitle {list-style-type: none; margin-left: -2em;}

.viewer .button {
border: 1px solid [[ColorSeven]];
}

.viewer blockquote {
border-left: 3px solid #666;
}

.viewer table {
border: 2px solid #333;
}

.viewer th, thead td {
background: #996;
border: 1px solid #666;
color: [[ColorMainBackground]];
}

.viewer td, .viewer tr {
border: 1px solid #666;
}

.viewer pre {
border: 1px solid [[ColorSix]];
background: [[ColorFive]];
}

.viewer code {
color: [[ColorNine]];
}

.viewer hr {
border: 0;
border-top: dashed 1px #666;
color: #666;
}

.highlight, .marked {
background: [[ColorSix]];
}
/*}}}*/
/***
''The editor replaces the viewer in the tiddler'' /%------------------------------------------------%/
***/
/*{{{*/
.editor input {
border: 1px solid [[ColorThree]];
}

.editor textarea {
border: 1px solid [[ColorThree]];
width: 100%;
}

.editorFooter {
color: #aaa;
}

/*}}}*/

item.title: RssFeed
item.description: The RSS feed for this site is [[here|http://www.andreamoro.net/perm/tw/mytw.xml]]. Use it to keep abreast of the new additions to the site (you need an RSS reader to do that: [[FireFox|www.spreadfirefox.org]] has one).

item.title: SaveChanges
item.description: you should really save your changes
